Real-Time Price Indices of a Heterogeneous Product from Online Advertisements

Application for the Hungarian Used Cars Market

Marcell Granát | Education & Research Expert at

Coauthor: Péter Vékás

2024


  https://marcellgranat.com/

Introduction

Motivation

  • Modern technologies allow for better statistical analysis of economic indicators like inflation (Cavallo and Rigobon 2016)

  • The car is a significant part of the consumption basket, accounting for 5% in Hungary (Hungarian Central Statistical Office 2022)

  • This research aims to provide a model framework for a daily inflation index (for the car market)

Challenges in Creating a Daily Inflation Index for Cars

Inflation: How much more expensive is the same car today than yesterday???

But cars are heterogeneous = We will not be able to find the same car today as yesterday.

They have countless properties that vary. The challenge is similar to housing indexes.

Important Criteria for an Inflation Index

Based on Mark and Goldberg (1984):

  1. Conceptually sound

  2. Administratively simple

  3. Reasonably stable and not overly dependent on changes in transactions or samples

Two Main Approaches for Heterogeneous Goods1

Repeat sales

Uses a fraction of data that are sold in both compared periods.

Hedonic regression

Model contains periodic dummy variables for quality-adjusted price change

  1. Based on Case and Shiller (1987)

A Issues with These Approaches

Repeat sales: Fraction of repeat sales are close to zero.

Hedonic regression

  • Model needs to be re-estimated if new observations are added (the model and former estimations change)

  • Assumes utility of certain characteristics is constant over time, which is not true for the car market (Requena-Silvente and Walker 2006)

Framework

Data

Data Source

Downloaded data of cars available on the website hasznaltauto.hu daily for 10 months starting in May of 2022

Assumption

Grouped vehicles by the day they were sold, assuming that if a car is no longer available on the website, then it has been sold for the last indicated price.

Advantages of Online-based Inflation Calculation

  • Cost reduction compared to traditional methods

  • No censored price spells (Cavallo and Rigobon 2016)

Bargaining

Bargaining may cause some inaccuracy in our index since we derive it from offer prices. But if this amount is time-invariant, then the comparison of the price level between periods (inflation) may remain accurate.

Cleaning steps

mutate(
  raw_cars_data,
  evjarat = gsub("/.*", "", evjarat),
  evjarat = as.numeric(evjarat),
  kilometerora_allasa = str_remove_all(kilometerora_allasa, "\\D"),
  kilometerora_allasa = as.numeric(kilometerora_allasa),
  szallithato_szem_szama = str_remove_all(szallithato_szem_szama, "\\D"),
  szallithato_szem_szama = as.integer(szallithato_szem_szama),
  szallithato_szem_szama = ifelse(szallithato_szem_szama > 60, NA, szallithato_szem_szama),
  ajtok_szama = as.numeric(ajtok_szama),
  ajtok_szama = ifelse(ajtok_szama == 1, NA, ajtok_szama),
  ajtok_szama = as.factor(ajtok_szama),
  szin = str_to_lower(szin),
  szin = case_when(
    str_detect(szin, "kék") ~ "kek",
    str_detect(szin, "ibolya") ~ "kek",
    str_detect(szin, "türkiz") ~ "kek",
    str_detect(szin, "piros") ~ "piros",
    str_detect(szin, "vörös") ~ "piros",
    str_detect(szin, "bordó") ~ "piros",
    str_detect(szin, "fekete") ~ "fekete",
    str_detect(szin, "szürke") ~ "szurke",
    str_detect(szin, "ezüst") ~ "szurke",
    str_detect(szin, "fehér") ~ "feher",
    str_detect(szin, "barna") ~ "barna",
    str_detect(szin, "homok") ~ "barna",
    str_detect(szin, "pezsgő") ~ "barna",
    str_detect(szin, "bézs") ~ "barna",
    str_detect(szin, "vaj") ~ "barna",
    str_detect(szin, "zöld") ~ "zold",
    str_detect(szin, "narancs") ~ "narancs",
    str_detect(szin, "sárga") ~ "sarga",
    str_detect(szin, "lila") ~ "lila",
    TRUE ~ "other"
  ),
  klima_fajtaja = ifelse(is.na(klima_fajtaja), "Nincs klíma", klima_fajtaja),
  klima_fajtaja = ifelse(klima_fajtaja == "Hőszivattyús klíma", "Automata klíma", klima_fajtaja), # merge top categories <- prop(hoszivattyus < .01)
  hengerurtartalom = str_remove_all(hengerurtartalom, "\\D"),
  hengerurtartalom = as.numeric(hengerurtartalom),
  teljesitmeny = gsub(".*kW, ", "", teljesitmeny),
  teljesitmeny = str_remove_all(teljesitmeny, "\\D"),
  teljesitmeny = as.numeric(teljesitmeny),
  muszaki_vizsga_ervenyes = gsub("/.*", "", muszaki_vizsga_ervenyes),
  muszaki_vizsga_ervenyes = as.numeric(muszaki_vizsga_ervenyes),
  muszaki_vizsga_ervenyes = muszaki_vizsga_ervenyes - 2021,
  muszaki_vizsga_ervenyes = ifelse(muszaki_vizsga_ervenyes < 0, "none", muszaki_vizsga_ervenyes),
  muszaki_vizsga_ervenyes = as.character(muszaki_vizsga_ervenyes),
  muszaki_vizsga_ervenyes = ifelse(is.na(muszaki_vizsga_ervenyes), "none", muszaki_vizsga_ervenyes),
  muszaki_vizsga_ervenyes = factor(muszaki_vizsga_ervenyes, levels = c("none", as.character(0:15)), ordered = TRUE),
  sajat_tomeg = str_remove_all(sajat_tomeg, "\\D"),
  sajat_tomeg = as.numeric(sajat_tomeg),
  teljes_tomeg = str_remove_all(teljes_tomeg, "\\D"),
  teljes_tomeg = as.numeric(teljes_tomeg),
  csomagtarto = str_remove_all(csomagtarto, "\\D"),
  csomagtarto = as.numeric(csomagtarto),
  brand = str_remove(id, "/.*"),
  nyari_gumi_meret2 = gsub(".*/", "", nyari_gumi_meret),
  nyari_gumi_meret2 = str_sub(nyari_gumi_meret2, end = 2),
  nyari_gumi_meret3 = gsub(".*R", "", nyari_gumi_meret),
  nyari_gumi_meret = gsub("/.*", "", nyari_gumi_meret),
  across(starts_with("nyari_gumi_meret"), str_trim),
  across(starts_with("nyari_gumi_meret"), as.integer),
  sebessegvalto_fokozatszam = str_remove_all(sebessegvalto_fajtaja, "\\D"),
  sebessegvalto_fokozatszam = as.numeric(sebessegvalto_fokozatszam),
  sebessegvalto_fokozatszam = ifelse(is.na(sebessegvalto_fokozatszam), 0, sebessegvalto_fokozatszam),
  sebessegvalto_fajtaja = case_when(
    str_detect(sebessegvalto_fajtaja, "tiptronic") ~ "tiptronic",
    str_detect(sebessegvalto_fajtaja, "zekvenciális") ~ "szekvenciális",
    str_detect(sebessegvalto_fajtaja, "anuális") ~ "manuáis",
    str_detect(sebessegvalto_fajtaja, "utomata") ~ "automata",
    TRUE ~ "other"
  )
)

Methodology

Clustering

  • The Central Statistical Office (KSH) selects representatives based on: Manufacturer, Engine size & Year of manufacture. Representatives are formed by averaging prices (20-30 representatives).

  • We believe that two products are not distinct categories solely due to price differences.

    • Differences in numerous characteristics should reflect in separate categories.

    • Price similarity at a specific time doesn’t rule out divergent price trends over the reference period.

Clustering

Clustering

ML predictive models

Engines

We apply multiple regression models to predict the price level.

  1. LASSO

  2. SVM

  3. Decision tree

  4. MARS

  5. Random Forest

  6. XGBoost

Workflow

#>

#>   penalty = tune()
#>   mixture = 1
#> 
#> Computational engine: glmnet

Tuning

Issue

Traditional cross-validation is inappropriate in the presence of inflation.

Solution

Observations of each day were split into an analysis (3/4) and an assessment set (1/4) using stratified sampling by the price and we tuned the models to reach lowest average RMSE (on the log of the the prices).

Tuning

#> # A tibble: 230 × 2

Tuning results

The price level

  1. We estimated the price of each item in the “representative basket” (cluster centres)

  2. Calculate the weighted mean of them (w = # of cars in the cluster \(\times\) predicted value)

  3. Compare each day’s weighted mean to the first day’s weighted mean

The price level

Issues with the inflation index

From the figures shown, it can be seen that the wigglenes (fluctuation) of the index we generated is very high. This is obviously unrealistic, as the value of a car cannot change by 5-10% continuously from one day to another.

To quantify the wiggleness, we apply the following measure:

\[ \text{Wiggleness} = \sum_{t=1}^T\Delta\Delta V_t^2, \]

where \(V\) is the values of index.

Issues with the inflation index

The smallest wiggleness occurs in the case of XGBoost, and its value decreases further with the increase of the number of clusters.

Influence of the sample size

Influence of the sample size

sorted_by_time_grouping <- function(data, min_n = 3000, date_col = time) {
  # * ensuring that there is enough observation for each window
  # grouping the data by time
  # ! and resetting the cumulative count when a threshold is exceeded
  data |> 
    group_by(tw_id = lubridate::ceiling_date({{ date_col }}, "days")) |> 
    nest() |> 
    arrange(tw_id) |> 
    ungroup() |> 
    mutate(
      n = map_dbl(data, nrow),
      # if excessed the target minimum, then start again
      cum_n = accumulate(n, .init = 0, .f = ~ {
        if (.x %/% min_n > 0) {
          .y
        } else {
          .x + .y # cumulate observations if not
        }
      }) |> 
        tail(- 1), # starts with 0
      g = rev(cumsum(rev(cum_n > min_n)))
    ) |> 
    mutate(
      .by = g,
      tw_id = max(tw_id)
    ) |> 
    select(tw_id, data) |> 
    unnest(data) |>
    nest(.by = tw_id)
}

Influence of the sample size

Seasonality? - Not really

Influence of variables

A model with which we estimate the index is different every day.

It is possible that the model estimates the value of certain properties very high on one day, and very low on another day.

With LIME, we can examine which properties the model considers important on certain days and how it influences the value of the fluctuating cluster center.

Influence of variables
